statement.tex: %text Two messengers $M_A$ and $M_B$ started running towards each other from points $A$ and $B$, $98$ km apart. They met $7$ hours later. On the way back, $M_A$ ran $1$km/h slower than before, while $M_B$ ran $1$km/h faster than before, thus returning two hours earlier than $M_A$. What were the original speeds of $M_A$ and $M_B$? %

step.context: %text If the messengers run at speeds $S_A$ and $S_B$ towards each other and meet after $7$ hours, is the following correct? %
step.reason: %text Since the messengers are running towards each other, we know that between them they covered the $98$ km stretch in $7$ hours. % \begin{align} &\therefore \overbrace{S_A(km/h)\times 7(h)}^\text{distance $M_A$}+ \overbrace{S_B(km/h)\times 7(h)}^\text{distance $M_B$}=98 \\ &\implies (S_A+S_B)\times 7=98 \\ &\implies S_A+S_B=14 \end{align}

step.context: %text On their return paths $M_A$, running $1$ km/h slower than before, takes two hours longer to get back than $M_B$ who is running $1$ km/h faster than before. Does the following equation capture this condition? %
\dfrac{7 S_A}{S_A-1}+2=\dfrac{7 S_B}{S_B+1} \\ S_A+S_B=14 \\ %text What are $S_A$ and $S_B$? %
step.reason: \dfrac{7 S_A}{S_A-1}+2=\dfrac{7 S_B}{S_B+1} \\ %text can be re-written as, % \begin{align} &{\small 7S_A(S_B+1)-7S_B(S_A-1)=2(S_A-1)(S_B-1)} \\ &\qquad\text{but }S_A+S_B=14, \\ &\therefore 14=2(14S_A-S_A^2)+S_A-14+S_A-1) \\ &\implies S_A^2-16S_A+64=0 \\ &\implies (S_A-8)^2=0 \implies S_A=8 \text{ km/h} \end{align} \\ \therefore S_B=14-8=6\text{ km/h}
